Clinical: Asthma. Coma. Diphtheria. Epilepsy. Headache. Syncope. Tetanus. Urticaria.
Characteristics: The symptoms of Amygdala are not very distinguishable from those of Hydrocyanic acid, but these may be taken as indicating its use: An excessively brilliant appearance of the eyes without corresponding mental expression. Heaviness in forehead (also Lauro.). Dulness of l. half of the head (Hydro. ac., right). Head drawn backward. Eyes drawn to left side. Burning heat in laringo-pharyngeal region. Lancinating pains through tonsils (Farrington). Palate end fauces dark reel. Swallowing impossible. Vomiting of undigested food and bile. Convulsive and at intervals very short respiration, with fear of suffocation.
